   No. 99–6310. Susan Baba, Petitioner v. Japan Travel Bureau Inter-
national, Inc., et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari dismissed. See Rule
39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the
Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in non-criminal
matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
is paid and the petition is submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See
Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992)
(per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See Martin v. District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1, 4 (1992) (Stevens, J., dissenting),
and cases cited.
                        Habeas Corpus Denied
   No. 99–6799. In Re Jeffrey Edwards, Petitioner;
   No. 99–6915. In Re Jerry Mack Dorrough, Petitioner; and
   No. 99–6916. In Re David Glen Harris, Petitioner. Petitions for writs
of habeas corpus denied.
   No. 99–6673. In Re Melvin Leroy Tyler, Petitioner. Motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and the petition
for writ of habeas corpus dismissed. See Rule 39.8.

                          Mandamus Denied
 No. 99–6657. In Re Milton J. Taylor, Petitioner. Petition for writ of
mandamus denied.

   No. 99–6532. In Re Delbert H. Reidt, Petitioner. Motion of peti-

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 98–1904. United States, et al., Petitioners v. Leslie R. Weather-
head. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit with directions to order
the vacation of the judgment of the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Washington and to dismiss the case as moot.
Justice Scalia dissents.
JNL99$1206—12-18-99 10:37:43     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)               MONDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1999                     387
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                      Order in Pending Cases
   No. 99M44. Charlotte Randall, Petitioner v. George S. Wass. Motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time
denied.
   No. 99M45. Robert Tolbert, et ux., Petitioners v. Commissioner of
Internal Revenue. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ
of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 99M46. Local 496, Laborers’ International Union of North
America, Petitioner v. Davine Alexander, et al. Motion to direct the
Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 98–1701. United States, Petitioner v. Gary Locke, Governor of
Washington, et al.; and
   No. 98–1706. International Association of Independent Tanker Own-
ers (Intertanko), Petitioner v. Gary Locke, Governor of Washington, et
al. Motion of Counties of Pierce, Mason, and Skagit to join brief amici
curiae of Washington Counties of San Juan, et al., denied.
   No. 98–1828. Vermont Agency of Natural Resources, Petitioner v.
United States, ex rel. Jonathan Stevens. Motion of Federation of Amer-
ican Health Systems for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted.
Motion of FMC Corporation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
granted. Motion of Friends of the Earth, et al., for leave to file a brief
as amici curiae granted. Motion of Chamber of Commerce of the
United States, et al., for leave to file a brief as amici curiae granted.
Motion of Project on Government Oversight for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae granted. Motion of National Employment Lawyers
Association for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted. Motion
of Taxpayers Against Fraud for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
granted. Motion of American Petroleum Institute, et al., for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae granted. Motion of American Clinical Labo-
ratory Association for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted.

   No. 99–6444. Ann Paveletz, Petitioner v. United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Third Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis denied. Petitioner allowed until December 27, 1999,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to
submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this
Court.
   No. 99–6615. Michael Wayne Williams, Petitioner v. John Taylor,
Warden. Motion for appointment of counsel granted, and it is ordered
that Barbara L. Hartung, Esq., of Richmond, Virginia, is appointed to
serve as counsel for petitioner in this case.

                        Certiorari Granted

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                               Opinions
  No. 98–1101. Rohn F. Drye, Jr., et al., Petitioners v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
  No. 98–678. Los Angeles Police Department, Petitioner v. United
Reporting Publishing Corporation. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice
Scalia, with whom Justice Thomas joins. Concurring opinion by Justice
Ginsburg, with whom Justice O’Connor, Justice Souter, and Justice
Breyer join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice
Kennedy joins.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 99–200. Ann McClure, Document Custodian, et al., Petitioners
v. Stephen Amelkin, Broadway Chiropractic, et al. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Cir-
cuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Los Angeles Police Department v.
United Reporting Publishing Corporation, 528 U. S. ––– (1999).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 99M47. The Hou Hawaiians, et al., Petitioners v. Benjamin Caye-
tano, Governor of Hawaii, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a
petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
  No. 99M48. Bobby Terrell Sheppard, Petitioner v. Ohio. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency
executed by petitioner granted.
  No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. Motion of the Special Master for compensation and reim-
bursement of expenses granted, and the Special Master awarded a total
of $84,772.75 for the period June 1, 1999 through December 1, 1999, to
be paid as follows: 34% by Nebraska, 34% by Wyoming, 5% by Colo-
rado, 24% by the United States, and 3% by Basin Electric Power
Cooperative.

(JOURNAL)              TUESDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1999                  427
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                        Certiorari Denied
   No. 99–817. Sam Felder, Jr., aka Sammie Felder, Petitioner v. Gary
L. Johnson, Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institu-
tional Division. Application for stay of execution of sentence of death
presented to Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court denied.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit denied. Justice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer would grant the application for stay of execution.

   No. 99–387. Thomas E. Raleigh, Chapter 7 Trustee for Estate of
William J. Stoecker, Petitioner v. Illinois Department of Revenue. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Seventh Circuit granted. Brief of petitioner to be filed with the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Tuesday,
February 22, 2000. Brief of respondent to be filed with the Clerk and
served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Thursday, March 23,
2000. Reply brief, if any, to be filed with the Clerk and served upon
opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Monday, April 10, 2000. Rule 29.2
does not apply.
   No. 99–579. Harris Trust and Savings Bank, etc., et al., Petitioners
v. Salomon Brothers, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted. Brief
of petitioners to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing coun-
sel on or before 3 p.m., Tuesday, February 22, 2000. Brief of respond-
ents to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Thursday, March 23, 2000. Reply brief, if any, to be filed
with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m.,
Monday, April 10, 2000. Rule 29.2 does not apply.
   No. 99–7000. Bobby Lee Ramdass, Petitioner v. Ronald J. Angelone,
Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. Motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition. Brief of peti-
tioner to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on
or before 3 p.m., Tuesday, February 22, 2000. Brief of respondent to be
filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3
p.m., Thursday, March 23, 2000. Reply brief, if any, to be filed with the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Monday,
April 10, 2000. Rule 29.2 does not apply.

submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste-

Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1.

(JOURNAL)               TUESDAY, JANUARY 11, 2000                   483
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                               Opinions
   No. 98–1299. New York, Petitioner v. Michael Hill. On writ of certio-
rari to the Court of Appeals of New York. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals of New York for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Scalia.
   No. 98–791. J. Daniel Kimel, Jr., et al., Petitioners v. Florida Board
of Regents, et al.; and
   No. 98–796. United States, Petitioner v. Florida Board of Regents,
et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O’Connor.
Opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Souter, Justice Gins-
burg, and Justice Breyer join, dissenting in part and concurring in part.
Opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Kennedy joins, concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part.

                               Opinions
  No. 98–822. Friends of the Earth, Incorporated, et al., Petitioners v.
Laidlaw Environmental Services (TOC), Inc. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg. Concurring opinion
by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Thomas joins.
  No. 98–7809. Salvador Martinez, Petitioner v. Court of Appeal of
California, Fourth Appellate District. On writ of certiorari to the Su-
preme Court of California. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Ste-
vens. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring opinion by
Justice Breyer. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment.
  No. 98–1036. Illinois, Petitioner v. William aka Sam Wardlow. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Illinois for further pro-
ceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
The Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Sou-
ter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join, concurring in part and
dissenting in part.
  No. 98–1464. Janet Reno, Attorney General, et al., Petitioners v.
Charlie Condon, Attorney General of South Carolina, et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.
Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The Chief Justice.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “The Court today has certified and filed with the Clerk a per curiam
opinion that will not otherwise be announced.”

                        Attorney Discipline
   No. D–2137. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas M. Gereighty.
Thomas M. Gereighty, of New Orleans, Louisiana, is suspended from
the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2138. In the Matter of Disbarment of Adair D. Jones. Adair
D. Jones, of Baton Rouge, Louisiana, is suspended from the practice of
law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2139. In the Matter of Disbarment of Albert L. Hencke. Al-
bert L. Hencke, of Blue Springs, Missouri, is suspended from the prac-
tice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40
days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court.

  The Court will take a recess from Monday, January 24, 2000, until
Tuesday, February 22, 2000.

                                Opinions
   No. 98–1255. United States, Petitioner v. Abel Martinez-Salazar. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
Concurring opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice Scalia, with
whom Justice Kennedy joins, concurring in the judgment.
   No. 98–1037. George Smith, Warden, Petitioner v. Lee Robbins. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Ginsburg
joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice Stevens,
Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join.
   No. 99–51. Carl T. C. Gutierrez and Madeleine Z. Bordallo, Petition-
ers v. Joseph F. Ada and Felix P. Camacho. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.
   No. 99–5746. Lonnie Weeks, Jr., Petitioner v. Ronald J. Angelone,
Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens, with whom Justice Ginsburg and Justice Breyer join, and with
whom Justice Souter joins with respect to all but Part I.

                       Certiorari Disposition
   No. 98–1427. M. C. Kramer, Warden, Petitioner v. Dwayne A. Davis.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Smith
v. Robbins, 528 U. S. ––– (2000).
   No. 99–451. Gail Lewis, Warden, et al., Petitioners v. Jesus Garcia
Delgado. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Smith v. Robbins, 528 U. S. ––– (2000).

   No. 99–671. W. Greg Shelton, Petitioner v. Benefit Plan of Exxon
Corporation and Participating Affiliates, et al. Petition for writ of cer-

                               Opinions
  No. 98–963. Jeremiah W. (Jay) Nixon, Attorney General of Missouri,
et al., Petitioners v. Shrink Missouri Government PAC, et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.
JNL99$0124—02-04-00 17:33:35     JOURNAPGT          MILES




542                      MONDAY, JANUARY 24, 2000

Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Justice
Breyer, with whom Justice Ginsburg joins. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Jus-
tice Scalia joins.
   No. 98–405. Janet Reno, Attorney General, Appellant v. Bossier Par-
ish School Board; and
   No. 98–406. George Price, et al., Appellants v. Bossier Parish School
Board. On appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Columbia. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring
opinion by Justice Thomas. Opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Jus-
tice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join, concurring in
part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with
whom Justice Ginsburg joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer.


  Adjourned until Tuesday, February 22, 2000, at 10 o’clock.


                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 99–6723. Anthony Braden Bryan, Petitioner v. Michael W.
Moore, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. In light of the representation
by the State of Florida, through its Attorney General, that petitioner’s
“death sentence will be carried out by lethal injection, unless petitioner
affirmatively elects death by electrocution” pursuant to the recent
amendments to Section 922.10 of the Florida Statutes, the writ of cer-
tiorari is dismissed as improvidently granted.


                         Certiorari Denied
  No. 99–7701. Billy George Hughes, Jr., Petitioner v. Gary L. Johnson,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
Application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit denied. Justice Stevens and Justice Ginsburg would grant the
application for stay of execution.

opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, March 3, 2000. Brief of
respondents to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing coun-
sel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, March 31, 2000. Reply brief, if any, to
be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before
3 p.m., Monday, April 17, 2000. Rule 29.2 does not apply.

   No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, Complainant v. State of California,

   No. 99–312. Norfolk Southern Railway Company, Petitioner v. Dedra

leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae denied.

                         Certiorari Denied
  No. 99–6675. Terry Sims, Petitioner v. Michael W. Moore, Secretary,
Florida Department of Corrections. In light of the recent amendments
to Section 922.10 of the Florida Statutes (providing that capital prison-
ers will be executed by lethal injection unless they affirmatively elect
execution by electrocution), and the Florida Supreme Court’s recent
conclusion that those amendments do not violate article X, section 9 of
the Florida Constitution, Sims v. Florida, Nos. SC00–295, SC00–297,
––– So. 2d –––, (Feb. 16, 2000), petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Florida denied.

Robert F. Malerba, of Huntington, New York, having requested to re-
sign as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name
be stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to the practice of law
before this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, issued on January 10, 2000,
is discharged.

returnable within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

(JOURNAL)               MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 2000                    617
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 98–1473. Michael Carrillo, Warden, Petitioner v. Adrian Salmon.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Roe v. Flores-
Ortega, 528 U. S. ––– (2000).
   No. 98–1967. F. W. Woolworth Company and Kinney Shoe Corpora-
tion, Petitioners v. Franchise Tax Board. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate District. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate Dis-
trict, for further consideration in light of Hunt-Wesson, Inc. v. Fran-
chise Tax Board of California, 528 U. S. ––– (2000).
   No. 98–9701. Jose Luis Sarroca, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec-
ond Circuit for further consideration in light of Roe v. Flores-Ortega,
528 U. S. ––– (2000).
   No. 99–5699. Larry Leonard Rice, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Roe v. Flores-
Ortega, 528 U. S. ––– (2000).
   No. 99–5951. Jesus Radillo-Contreras, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
jnl99$0228—03-08-00 07:07:52   JOURNAPGT            MILES




618                     MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 2000

for the Eleventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Roe v.
Flores-Ortega, 528 U. S. ––– (2000).
  No. 99–6233. Roderick W. Miller, Petitioner v. George Kaloroumakis,
Administrator, Eastern Correctional Institution, et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Roe v. Flores-Ortega, 528 U. S.
––– (2000).

for the Eleventh Circuit denied. Justice Breyer took no part in the

   No. 99–7884. Thomas L. Apple, Petitioner v. John Glenn, Former

Justice took no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
   No. 99–7909. Michael Sindram, Petitioner v. United States. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari dismissed. See Rule 39.8.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

                      Order in Pending Cases
   No. 99A750. James B. Hunt, Governor of North Carolina, et al., Ap-
pellants v. Martin Cromartie, et al.; and
   No. 99A757. Alfred Smallwood, et al., Appellants v. Martin Cromar-
tie, et al. Applications for stay of judgment of the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina, case No. 4:96–
CV–104–B(3), entered March 8, 2000, presented to The Chief Justice
and by him referred to the Court granted pending the timely docketing
of appeals in this Court. Should the jurisdictional statements be timely
filed, this order shall remain in effect pending this Court’s action on
the appeals. If appeals are dismissed, or judgment is affirmed, this
order shall terminate automatically. In the event jurisdiction is noted
or postponed, this order will remain in effect pending the sending down
of the judgment of this Court.

                       Habeas Corpus Denied

  No. 99–8191. In Re Walter Helgoth, Petitioner;
  No. 99–8203. In Re Kurby Gerald Decker, Petitioner;
  No. 99–8213. In Re Thomas E. Smith, Petitioner;
  No. 99–8267. In Re Michael Darnell Harris, Petitioner;
  No. 99–8275. In Re Dele Adio-Mowo, Petitioner;
  No. 99–8288. In Re Quordalis Sanders, Petitioner;
  No. 99–8380. In Re Brenda Haynes, et vir, Petitioners;
  No. 99–8395. In Re James Murray, Petitioner;
  No. 99–8427. In Re Onofre T. Serrano, Petitioner; and
  No. 99–8441. In Re Bill Saunders, Petitioner. Petitions for writs of
habeas corpus denied.
  No. 99–8425. In Re Billy Holmes Richards, Petitioner. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition
for writ of habeas corpus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has
repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to
accept any further petitions in non-criminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste-
vens dissents. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals,
506 U. S. 1, 4 (1992) (Stevens, J., dissenting), and cases cited.

                         Attorney Discipline
   No. D–2148. In the Matter of Disbarment of William T. Stone. Wil-
liam T. Stone, of Williamsburg, Virginia, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2149. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stephen L. Raskin.
Stephen L. Raskin, of South Miami, Florida, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

                          MONDAY, MARCH 27, 2000                  719
   No. D–2150. In the Matter of Disbarment of N. David Korones. N.
David Korones, of St. Petersburg, Florida, is suspended from the prac-
tice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40
days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2151. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert L. Travis, Jr.
Robert L. Travis, Jr., of Tallahassee, Florida, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2152. In the Matter of Disbarment of Timothy S. Haley. Timo-
thy S. Haley, of Caldwell, New Jersey, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.

  The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 3, 2000, until Mon-
day, April 17, 2000 at 10 o’clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                                Opinions

  No. 98–1993. Florida, Petitioner v. J. L. On writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Gins-
burg. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom The Chief
Justice joins.
   No. 99–137. J. Wayne Garner, Former Chairman of the State Board
of Pardons and Paroles of Georgia, et al., Petitioners v. Robert L. Jones.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part in the judgment.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice Stevens and
Justice Ginsburg join.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                                Opinion

  No. 98–1161. City of Erie, et al., Petitioners v. Pap’s A.M., tdba
“Kandyland”. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylva-
nia, Western District. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Western District, for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Justice O’Connor
announced the judgment of the Court and delivered the opinion of the
Court with respect to Parts I and II, and an opinion with respect to
Parts III and IV, in which The Chief Justice, Justice Kennedy, and
Justice Breyer join. Opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice
Thomas joins, concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Souter,
concurring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens, with whom Justice Ginsburg joins.

(JOURNAL)                   MONDAY, APRIL 3, 2000                      727
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and Justice Ginsburg. The Chief Jus-
tice said:
   “It is my sad duty to announce the death on March 28th of Mary
Fowler Brennan, the widow of our late colleague, Justice William J.
Brennan, Jr.
   “On behalf of the Court and retired Justice White, I extend profound
sympathy to her family. It will be recorded on the Court’s minutes that
the recess the Court takes today will be in memory of Mary Fowler
Brennan.
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 99–5436. Roosevelt Williams, Petitioner v. Wisconsin. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the Supreme Court of Wisconsin for further consideration in light of
Florida v. J. L., 529 U. S. ––– (2000).
   No. 99–7592. Willie Morrison, Petitioner v. Ohio. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Cuyahoga County. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Cuyahoga County, for further consider-
ation in light of Florida v. J. L., 529 U. S. ––– (2000).

   No. 99M76. Lonnie T. Payne, Petitioner v. William Jennings, et al.

time denied.

fense. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari
out-of-time denied.

liam M. Scalf, of Corbin, Kentucky, is suspended from the practice of

practice of law in this Court.

                               Opinion
  No. 99–391. Robin Free, et al., Petitioners v. Abbott Laboratories,
Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed by an equally divided Court.
Opinion per curiam announced by The Chief Justice. Justice O’Connor
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                         Certiorari Denied
  No. 99–9077. Robert Lee Tarver, Petitioner v. Alabama. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy
and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of Alabama denied.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                        Attorney Discipline
  No. D–2155. In the Matter of Disbarment or Other Discipline of
Teddy I. Moore. Teddy I. Moore, of Flushing New York, is suspended
from the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court or otherwise disci-
plined. Dissenting statement by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice
Breyer joins: “In my opinion Teddy I. Moore should be reprimanded
for his unprofessional conduct and also admonished that future miscon-
duct of the same sort will be sanctioned more severely.”

JNL99$0417—07-14-00 17:07:31    JOURNAPGT         MILES




784                      MONDAY, APRIL 17, 2000

                         Oral Arguments
   No. 99–387. Thomas E. Raleigh, Chapter 7 Trustee for the Estate
of William J. Stoecker, Petitioner v. Illinois Department of Revenue.
Argued by Mr. Robert Radasevich for the petitioner, by Mr. Benjamin
Goldgar for the respondent, and by Mr. Lawrence G. Wallace for the
United States as amicus curiae, by special leave of the Court.
   No. 99–579. Harris Trust and Savings Bank, etc., et al., Petitioners
v. Salomon Smith Barney Inc., et al. Argued by Mr. Robert A. Long
for the petitioners, by Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann for the United States as
amicus curiae, by special leave of the Court, and by Mr. Peter C. Hein
for the respondents.

                                 Orders
  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Bankruptcy
Rules 1017, 2002(a), 4003, 4004, and 5003.
  2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Bank-
ruptcy Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 2000, and shall gov-
ern in all proceedings in bankruptcy cases thereafter commenced and,
insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
  3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Bankruptcy Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section
2075 of Title 28, United States Code.
  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure for the United States
District Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including therein
amendments to Civil Rules 4, 5, 12, 14, 26, 30, and 37 and to Rules B,
C, and E of the Supplemental Rules for Certain Admiralty and Mari-
time Claims.
  2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Civil Pro-
cedure and the Supplemental Rules for Certain Admiralty and Mari-
time Claims shall take effect on December 1, 2000, and shall govern all
proceedings in civil cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just
and practicable, all proceedings in civil cases then pending.
  3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Civil Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.
JNL99$0417—04-26-00 15:22:09    JOURNAPGT          MILES




                         MONDAY, APRIL 17, 2000                   785
   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure for the United
States District Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including
therein amendments to Criminal Rules 7, 31, 32, and 38, and new
Rule 32.2.
   2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 2000, and shall govern in
all proceedings in criminal cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as
just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
   3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072
of Title 28, United States Code.
   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Evidence for the United States District
Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including therein amend-
ments to Evidence Rules 103, 404, 701, 702, 703, 803(6), and 902.
   2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Evidence
shall take effect on December 1, 2000, and shall govern all proceedings
thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practicable, all proceed-
ings then pending.
   3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Evidence in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of Title 28,
United States Code.

  Adjourned until Tuesday, April 18, 2000, at 10 o’clock.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                               Opinions
   No. 99–6615. Michael Wayne Williams, Petitioner v. John Taylor,
Warden. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, and reversed in part,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy.
   No. 98–8384. Terry Williams, Petitioner v. John Taylor, Warden. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment reversed, and the case is remanded to the united
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Justice Stevens announced
the judgment of the court and delivered the opinion of the Court with
respect to Parts I, III, and IV, and an opinion with respect to Parts II
and V in which Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer
join. Justice O’Connor delivered the opinion of the Court with respect
to Part II (except as to the footnote), in which The Chief Justice, Jus-
tice Kennedy and Justice Thomas join, and in which Justice Scalia joins
except as to the footnote, and an opinion concurring in part and concur-
ring in the judgment in which Justice Kennedy joins. Opinion by The
Chief Justice, with whom Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas join, con-
curring in part and dissenting in part.

                           Oral Arguments
  No. 99–5525. Charles Thomas Dickerson, Petitioner v. United
States. Argued by Mr. James W. Hundley, appointed by this Court, for
the petitioner, by Mr. Seth P. Waxman for the respondent, and by Mr.
Paul G. Cassell as amicus curiae, at the invitation of the Court, in
support of the judgment below.
  No. 99–5716. Floyd J. Carter, Petitioner v. United States. Argued
by Mr. Donald McCauley for the petitioner and by Mr. David C. Fred-
erick for the respondent.


  Adjourned until Monday, April 24, 2000, at 10 o’clock.
JNL99$0424—04-29-00 17:05:29     JOURNAPGT         MILES




(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, APRIL 24, 2000                   793
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                  Appeal—Summary Disposition
   No. 99–1396. James L. Chandler, et al., Appellants v. Katherine Har-
ris, Secretary of State of Florida, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Florida. Judgment affirmed.

                Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 99–1401. Frank X. Hopkins, Warden, Petitioner v. John Byron
Newman. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Terry Williams v. Taylor, 529 U. S. ––– (2000).
   No. 99–5670. Alton Coleman, Petitioner v. Indiana. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Indiana. Motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certio-
rari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Indiana for further consideration in light of Terry Williams
v. Taylor, 529 U. S. ––– (2000).
   No. 99–6862. Gerald B. Thomas, Petitioner v. Mark L. Earley, Attor-
ney General of Virginia, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Terry Williams v. Taylor, 529 U. S. ––– (2000).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 99–658. Jaime Castillo, et al., Petitioners v. United States. Mo-
tion for appointment of counsel granted, and it is ordered that Stanley

                       Habeas Corpus Denied

                               MONDAY, MAY 1, 2000                 825
habeas corpus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in non-criminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                                   Opinions
  No. 98–1167. Edward Christensen, et al., Petitioners v. Harris
County, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Thomas. Concurring opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice
Scalia, concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Ginsburg and Justice
Breyer join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice
Ginsburg joins.
  No. 98–7540. Scott Leslie Carmell, Petitioner v. Texas. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Texas, Second District. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Texas, Second
District, for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens, announced by Justice O’Connor.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom The Chief Justice,
Justice O’Connor, and Justice Kennedy join.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, MAY 15, 2000                      835
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 99–437. Joseph Lehman, Secretary, Washington Department of
Corrections, Petitioner v. Donald MacFarlane and James Fogle. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit with instructions to dismiss the case as moot.

                     Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 99M85. Paul Sanwick, Petitioner v. Scott Carver, Warden. Mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied.
   No. 99–1489. Raquel, Petitioner v. Education Management Corpora-
tion, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
   No. 99–8025. Harry L. Bierley, Petitioner v. Shad Connelly, Judge,
Court of Common Pleas of Pennsylvania, Erie County, et al. Motion of
petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed in
forma pauperis denied.

                         Certiorari Denied
   No. 99–592. Gary Collins, et al., Petitioners v. Spokane Valley Fire
Protection District No. l, etc.; and
   No. 99–788. Spokane Valley Fire Protection District No. 1, Peti-
tioner v. Gary Collins, et al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.

edly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
any further petitions in non-criminal matters from petitioner unless
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and the petition is
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste-
vens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                                Opinions
   No. 98–1991. Public Lands Council, et al., Petitioners v. Bruce Bab-
bitt, Secretary of the Interior, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Breyer. Concurring opinion by Justice O’Connor
with whom Justice Thomas joins.
   No. 99–5153. Cornell Johnson, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice Ken-
nedy concurring in part. Opinion by Justice Thomas concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia.
   No. 99–116. Jeffrey Allan Fischer, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Thomas with whom Justice Scalia joins.
   No. 99–5. United States, Petitioner v. Antonio J. Morrison, et al.; and
   No. 99–29. Christy Brzonkala, Petitioner v. Antonio J. Morrison, et
al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by The Chief Justice.
Concurring opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Souter with whom Justice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice
Breyer join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer with whom Justice
Stevens joins, and with whom Justice Souter and Justice Ginsburg join
as to Part I–A.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, MAY 22, 2000                     863
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 99–1227. Bryon L. Rosquist, D. C., P.C., et al., Petitioners v.
Melanie McCann, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration
in light of United States v. Morrison, 529 U.S. ––– (2000).
   No. 99–1583. Pennsylvania, Petitioner v. D. M. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, Eastern District, for
further consideration in light of Illinois v. Wardlow, 528 U. S. –––
(2000).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 99M87. Asya D. Zimbovsky, Petitioner v. Massachusetts. Motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time
under Rule 14.5 denied.
  No. 99M88. Tillis Trucking Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Malachi
Moses, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of
certiorari out-of-time denied.
  No. 99M89. Cecilio Huertas Barbosa, et al., Petitioners v. Hospital
Alejandro Buitrago, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition
for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
  No. 99–1295. David A. Gitlitz, et ux., et al., Petitioners v. Commis-
sioner of Internal Revenue. Motion of the Solicitor General to dispense
with printing the joint appendix granted.
  No. 99–8264. Clinton W. Delespine, Petitioner v. Gary L. Johnson,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division,
JNL99$0522—06-01-00 17:10:27    JOURNAPGT          MILES




864                       MONDAY, MAY 22, 2000

et al. Motion of petitioner for reconsideration of order denying leave
to proceed in forma pauperis denied.
  No. 99–9052. Alexander Samuel, Petitioner v. Nathan’s Famous Op-
erating Corporation. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis denied. Petitioner allowed until June 12, 2000, within which
to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition
in compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.

                        Certiorari Granted
   No. 99–1257. Carol M. Browner, Administrator of Environmental
Protection Agency, et al., Petitioners v. American Trucking Associa-
tions, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted.

tioner v. United States Army Corps of Engineers, et al. Motion of
Pacific Legal Foundation and Randy Peterson for leave to file a brief
as amici curiae granted. Motion of National Association of Home
Builders for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted. Motion of
American Farm Bureau Federation for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted.
   No. 99–1379. Circuit City Stores, Inc., Petitioner v. Saint Clair
Adams. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted limited to Question 1 presented
by the petition.
   No. 99–6218. Wilbert K. Rogers, Petitioner v. Tennessee. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Western Division,
granted.

peatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
JNL99$0522—06-01-00 17:10:27    JOURNAPGT         MILES




876                       MONDAY, MAY 22, 2000

any further petitions in non-criminal matters from petitioner unless
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and the petition is
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste-
vens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

  No. D–2160. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Patrick Tierney.
James Patrick Tierney, of Malibu, California, is suspended from the

from the practice of law in this Court.

                               Opinions

   No. 98–1811. Alexis Geier, et al., Petitioners v. American Honda
Motor Company, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg
join.
   No. 99–5739. Dewey J. Jones, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Thomas
JNL99$0522—06-01-00 17:10:27     JOURNAPGT         MILES




884                       MONDAY, MAY 22, 2000

joins. Concurring opinion by Justice Thomas with whom Justice
Scalia joins.
   No. 98–1682. United States, et al., Appellants v. Playboy Entertain-
ment Group, Inc. On appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Delaware. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Kennedy. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion
by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Breyer with whom The Chief Justice, Justice O’Con-
nor, and Justice Scalia join.
   No. 98–1828. Vermont Agency of Natural Resources, Petitioner v.
United States, ex rel., Jonathan Stevens. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Second Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by
Justice Breyer. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg with whom Justice Breyer
joins concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Souter joins.
  No. 98–9828. Maria Suzuki Ohler, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg,
and Justice Breyer join.

jnl99$0530—06-08-00 06:52:09   JOURNAPGT           MILES




(JOURNAL)                  TUESDAY, MAY 30, 2000                     895
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

    Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

  No. 99–1266. United States, Petitioner v. Robert Earl Johnson. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Jones v.
United States, 529 U. S. ––– (2000).
  No. 99–6136. Harvey Rea, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Jones v. United
States, 529 U. S. ––– (2000).

                      Orders in Pending Cases

  No. 129, Original. Commonwealth of Virginia, Plaintiff v. State of
Maryland. Motion of Audubon Naturalist Society for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae granted. Motion for leave to file a bill of complaint
granted. Defendant allowed 60 days within which to file an answer.
  No. 99–1403. Cement Masons Health and Welfare Trust Fund for
Northern California, et al., Petitioners v. Raymond Stone. Motion of
International Training Institute for Sheet Metal and Air Conditioning
Industry for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted. Motion of
Multiemployer Trust Funds for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
granted. Motion of Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas
Health and Welfare Fund for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
granted. Motion of Health Insurance Association of America for leave
jnl99$0530—06-08-00 06:52:09    JOURNAPGT           MILES




896                         TUESDAY, MAY 30, 2000

to file a brief as amicus curiae granted. The Solicitor General is invited
to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

   No. 99–8119. Victor Hugo Saldano, Petitioner v. Texas. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas for further consideration in
light of the confession of error by the Solicitor General of Texas.

                      Orders in Pending Cases

   No. 99M86. Dwight Ellis Brooks, Petitioner v. Citibank (South Da-
kota), N. A. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of
certiorari out-of-time under Rule 14.5 denied.
   No. 99M90. Neville Whitfield Riley, Petitioner v. Charles H. Arm-
strong. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari
out-of-time denied.
   No. 99M91. Marilyn L. Fuller, Petitioner v. Oregon Office for Serv-
ices to Children and Families, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file
a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
Motion of the River Master for fees and reimbursement of expenses
granted, and the River Master is awarded a total of $2,439.00 for the
period January 1–March 31, 2000, to be paid equally by the parties.
   No. 99–804. Carl W. Cleveland, Petitioner v. United States. Motion
of petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appendix granted.
  No. 99–1038. Eastern Associated Coal Corporation, Petitioner v.
United Mine Workers of America, District 17, et al. Motion of Institute
for a Drug-Free Workplace for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
granted.

936                        MONDAY, JUNE 5, 2000

                               Opinions
   No. 99–658. Jaime Castillo, et al., Petitioners v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer.
   No. 98–9537. Juatassa Sims, Petitioner v. Kenneth S. Apfel, Commis-
sioner of Social Security. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Justice Thomas announced the judgment of the Court and delivered
the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I and II–A, and an
opinion with respect to Part II–B, in which Justice Stevens, Justice
Souter, and Justice Ginsburg join. Opinion by Justice O’Connor concur-
ring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Breyer with whom The Chief Justice, Justice Scalia, and Justice
Kennedy join.
   No. 99–138. Jenifer Troxel, et vir, Petitioners v. Tommie Granville.
On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington. Judgment
affirmed. Justice O’Connor announced the judgment of the Court and
delivered an opinion in which The Chief Justice, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer join. Opinion by Justice Souter concurring in the judg-
ment. Opinion by Justice Thomas concurring in the judgment. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy.
   No. 99–166. United States, Petitioner v. Webster L. Hubbell. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District
of Columbia Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
Dissenting statement by The Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice Thomas with whom Justice Scalia joins.

(JOURNAL)                WEDNESDAY, JUNE 7, 2000                   941
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice

to the Supreme Court of Florida denied.

JNL99$0609—06-14-00 16:04:44      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                   FRIDAY, JUNE 9, 2000                      943
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 99–1702. Texas, Petitioner v. Raymond Levi Cobb. Application
for stay presented to Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court
granted, and it is ordered that the mandate of the Court of Criminal
Appeals of Texas, case No. 72,807, is hereby stayed pending the disposi-
tion of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ
of certiorari be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In the
event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall termi-
nate upon the issuance of the mandate of this Court.
JNL99$0612—06-16-00 18:33:08      JOURNAPGT         MILES




(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 12, 2000                     945
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 99–8458. Rogers Lee Jackson, Petitioner v. Kenneth S. Apfel,
Commissioner of Social Security. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Sims v. Apfel, 530 U. S. ––– (2000).

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 99A979. Jane Does 1, et al., Applicants v. Oregon, et al. Applica-
tion for stay addressed to Justice Thomas and referred to the Court
denied.
   No. 99M92. Dion Webb, Petitioner v. Attorney Grievance Commis-
sion. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari
out-of-time under Rule 14.5 denied.
   No. 99M93. Dexter Sharod Tarver, Petitioner v. Michael W. Moore,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. Motion to direct
the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 128, Original. State of Alaska, Plaintiff v. United States of
America. Motion for leave to file a bill of complaint granted. The United
States is allowed 60 days within which to file an answer.
   No. 99–1178. Solid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County, Peti-
tioner v. United States Army Corps of Engineers, et al. Motion of
Cargill, Inc., for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted.

                         Certiorari Denied
  No. 99–1225. Parsons Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. United
States, ex rel., Janet C. Oliver. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.

   No. 99–579. Harris Trust and Savings Bank, etc., et al., Petitioners
v. Salomon Smith Barney Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev-
enth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas.

certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

Justice Ginsburg with whom Justice Stevens, Justice Souter, and Jus-
tice Breyer join.

States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further proceed-

   No. 99–7000. Bobby Lee Ramdass, Petitioner v. Ronald J. Angelone,
Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Justice Kennedy announced the judgment of the Court and
delivered an opinion in which The Chief Justice, Justice Scalia, and
Justice Thomas join. Opinion by Justice O’Connor concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice

United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further pro-

tice O’Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Ginsburg.

   No. 98–1836. United States Healthcare Systems of Pennsylvania,

District, for further consideration in light of Pegram v. Herdrich, 530
U. S. ––– (2000).

Inc., Petitioners v. Art Huttinger, et ux., and James Fennern, et ux.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals

vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Reeves v. Sander-
son Plumbing Products, Inc., 530 U. S. ––– (2000).

pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As
the petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is
directed not to accept any further petitions in non-criminal matters
from petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid
and the petition is submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin
v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per cu-
riam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                               Opinions
  No. 8, Original. State of Arizona, Complainant v. State of California,
et al. On exceptions to the Report of the Special Master. Exception of
state parties overruled, Exceptions of United States and Quechan
Tribe sustained, Special Master’s recommendations to approve parties’
proposed settlements respecting Fort Mojave and Colorado River Res-
ervations are adopted, and parties are directed to submit to the Clerk
any objections they may have to the Special Master’s proposed supple-
mental decree before August 22, 2000. Outstanding water rights claims
associated with disputed Fort Yuma Reservation boundary remanded
JNL99$0619—02-24-01 20:26:28       JOURNAPGT        MILES




984                         MONDAY, JUNE 19, 2000

to the Special Master. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg. Opinion by The
Chief Justice, with whom Justice O’Connor and Justice Thomas join,
concurring in part and dissenting in part.
  No. 99–474. Stephen P. Crosby, Secretary of Administration and Fi-
nance of Massachusetts, et al., Petitioners v. National Foreign Trade
Council. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Souter.
Opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Justice Thomas joins concurring
in the judgment.
   No. 99–224. Charles B. Miller, Superintendent, Pendleton Correc-
tional Facility, et al., Petitioners v. Richard A. French, et al.; and
   No. 99–582. United States, Petitioner v. Richard A. French, et al..
On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed, and cases remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
O’Connor. Opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice Ginsburg joins
concurring in part and dissenting in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Breyer with whom Justice Stevens joins.
   No. 99–62. Santa Fe Independent School District, Petitioner v. Jane
Doe, Individually and as Next Friend for Her Minor Children, Jane
and John Doe, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice with whom Justice
Scalia and Justice Thomas join.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                         Certiorari Denied
  No. 99–9990. Thomas Harrison Provenzano, Petitioner v. Florida.
Application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida denied. Justice Ste-
vens and Justice Breyer would grant the petition for writ of certiorari
and application for stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)                 WEDNESDAY, JUNE 21, 2000                     991
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                          Certiorari Denied
  No. 99–10089. Thomas Harrison Provenzano, Petitioner v. Michael
W. Moore, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy
and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.


                        Habeas Corpus Denied
   No. 99–10090. In Re Thomas Harrison Provenzano, Petitioner. Ap-
plication for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Kennedy and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of
habeas corpus denied.


                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 99–9917. Russell William Burket, Petitioner v. Ronald J. Ange-
lone, Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. Application for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to The Chief Justice
and by him referred to the Court granted pending the disposition of
the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ of certio-
rari be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In the event the
petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall terminate upon
the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, JUNE 26, 2000                     995
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 99–935. Michael Chandler, Father and Next Friend of Jesse
Chandler, Petitioner v. Don Siegelman, Governor of Alabama and Presi-
dent of the Alabama State Board of Education, et al. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit for further consideration in light of Santa Fe Independent
School District v. Doe, 530 U. S. ––– (2000).
  No. 99–1264. James H. Brown, III, Petitioner v. Michael O’Dea, War-
den. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of Terry
Williams v. Taylor, 529 U. S. ––– (2000).

                      Order in Pending Cases
   No. 99M94. Harley Andrew Byrd, Petitioner v. Steve Salmon, Board
Chair, First Baptist Church of Warner. Motion to direct the Clerk to
file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. Motion of the Special Master for compensation and reim-
bursement of expenses granted, and the Special Master awarded a total
of $90,755.32 for the period December 2, 1999 through June 5, 2000, to
be awarded as follows: 40% by Nebraska, 40% by Wyoming, 3% by
Colorado, 12% by the United States, and 5% by Basin Electric Power
Cooperative.
   No. 99–1178. Solid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County, Peti-
tioner v. United States Army Corps of Engineers, et al. Motion of
petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appendix granted.

   No. D–2165. In the Matter of David Ferris Tamer. David Ferris
Tamer, of Winston-Salem, North Carolina, having requested to resign
as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to the practice of law be-
fore this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, issued on May 22, 2000,
is discharged.

of law in this Court.

                               Opinions

  No. 99–244. Mobil Oil Exploration and Producing Southeast, Inc.,
Petitioner v. United States; and
JNL99$0626—07-14-00 16:56:39     JOURNAPGT         MILES




1016                      MONDAY, JUNE 26, 2000

   No. 99–253. Marathon Oil Company, Petitioner v. United States. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fed-
eral Circuit. Judgment reversed, and cases remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
   No. 99–401. California Democratic Party, et al., Petitioners v. Bill
Jones, Secretary of State of California, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion
by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom
Justice Ginsburg joins as to Part I.
   No. 99–478. Charles C. Apprendi, Jr., Petitioner v. New Jersey. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Jersey. Judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court of New Jersey for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Con-
curring opinion by Justice Thomas with whom Justice Scalia joins as
to Parts I and II. Dissenting opinion by Justice O’Connor with whom
The Chief Justice, Justice Kennedy, and Justice Breyer join. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Breyer with whom The Chief Justice joins.
   No. 99–5525. Charles Thomas Dickerson, Petitioner v. United
States. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The
Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Justice
Thomas joins.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Wednesday, June 28, 2000, the Court will announce all the remain-
ing opinions ready during the Term of the Court.”


  Adjourned until Wednesday, June 28, 2000, at 10 o’clock.
