(JOURNAL)               WEDNESDAY, JUNE 28, 2000                   1019
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                               Opinions
   No. 99–830. Don Stenberg, Attorney General of Nebraska, et al.,
Petitioners v. Leroy Carhart. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion
by Justice Breyer. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens with whom
Justice Ginsburg joins. Concurring opinion by Justice O’Connor. Con-
curring opinion by Justice Ginsburg with whom Justice Stevens joins.
Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom The Chief
Justice joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas with whom The
Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join.
   No. 98–1648. Guy Mitchell, et al., Petitioners v. Mary L. Helms, et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the judgment of this Court. Justice Thomas an-
nounced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which
The Chief Justice, Justice Scalia, and Justice Kennedy join. Opinion by
Justice O’Connor, with whom Justice Breyer joins, concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice Ste-
vens and Justice Ginsburg join.
   No. 98–1856. Leila Jeanne Hill, Audrey Himmelmann, and Everitt
W. Simpson, Jr., Petitioners v. Colorado, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Colorado. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Concurring opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice
O’Connor, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Scalia with whom Justice Thomas joins. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Kennedy.
   No. 99–699. Boy Scouts of America and Monmouth Council, et al.,
Petitioners v. James Dale. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of New Jersey. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of New Jersey for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion
JNL99$0628—07-14-00 16:58:51    JOURNAPGT          MILES




1020                    WEDNESDAY, JUNE 28, 2000

by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter with whom
Justice Ginsburg and Justice Breyer join.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “I am authorized to announce, that the Court has acted on all cases
submitted for decision. Disposition of items scheduled for Conference
will be reflected on an Order List that will be released at 10 o’clock
tomorrow morning.
   “Accordingly, it is ordered that those cases remaining on the docket
but not ready for consideration, are continued to the session of the
Court beginning October 2, 2000.
   “The Court will be in recess from Thursday, June 29th until the first
Monday of October 2000, at which time the October 1999 Term of the
Court will be adjourned and the October 2000 Term of the Court will
convene as provided by statute.
   “The members of the Court thank all members of the Supreme Court
staff for their superb work and their dedication to duty during this
Term.
   “The Court, the Bar, and the public recognize the hard work, com-
mitment, and professionalism of the Court staff. Such faithful service
is exemplified by Jim Duff, my Administrative Assistant for the last
four years, who is leaving the Court this summer. Thank you, Jim, for
your outstanding service. The superb work done by the Court staff
contributes significantly to the accomplishment of the Court’s mission.”


                         Certiorari Denied
  No. 99–2079. Lazaro Gonzalez, Next Friend, or Alternatively, as
Temporary Legal Custodian, etc., Petitioner v. Janet Reno, Attorney
General, et al. Application for stay presented to Justice Kennedy and
by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.

   No. 98–1658. Mary L. Helms, etc., et al., Petitioners v. Cecil J. Picard,

   No. 98–1671. Cecil J. Picard, et al., Petitioners v. Mary L. Helms, et

Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The Court reversed the judgment below
in Mitchell v. Helms, 530 U. S. ––– (2000). Therefore, petitions for writs
of certiorari granted, and cases remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings.
   No. 99–1152. Hope Clinic, et al., Petitioners v. James Ryan, Attorney

United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Stenberg v. Carhart, 530 U. S. ––– (2000).

U. S. ––– (2000).

Alaska. On Bill of Complaint. Joint motion for entry of decree granted.

granted. Court retains jurisdiction to entertain such further proceed-
ings, enter such orders, and issue writs as from time to time may be
determined necessary or advisable to effectuate and supplement this
decree and the rights of respective parties. In all other respects, this
decree is final.
   No. 126, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Nebraska
and State of Colorado. Motion of Nebraska to dismiss denied, and case
recommitted to the Special Master for further proceedings.
   No. 130, Original. State of New Hampshire, Plaintiff v. State of
Maine. Motion for leave to file a bill of complaint granted, and defend-
ant allowed 60 days within which to file a motion to dismiss on res
judicata grounds. Plaintiff allowed 45 days to file a response to the
motion. The Solicitor General invited to file a brief expressing views
of the United States. Justice Souter took no part in the consideration
or decision of this order.

petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition
for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana dismissed. See
Rule 39.8.
  No. 99–9284. Robert E. Cotner, Petitioner v. Bobby Boone, Warden.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied,
and petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of
Oklahoma dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in non-criminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and the petition is submit-
ted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia
Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dis-
sents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 99–9306. Robert E. Cotner, Petitioner v. Court of Criminal Ap-
peals of Oklahoma, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the Su-
preme Court of Oklahoma dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has
repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to
accept any further petitions in non-criminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and the petition
is submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of
Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice
Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                        Attorney Discipline

counsel on or before 3 p.m., Monday, November 13, 2000. Brief of re-
spondents to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel
on or before 3 p.m., Wednesday, December 13, 2000. Reply brief, if any,
to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Friday, December 29, 2000. Rule 29.2 does not apply.
